lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/Starou.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Starou.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.
// JavaFX dependencies (tự động tải cho các OS: win, mac, linux)
Starou is a simple **task management chatbot** written in **Java**.
It allows you to add, list, find, mark, unmark, and delete tasks through simple text-based commands.
All tasks are automatically saved to a local file so you can pick up where you left off next time.
You can add a **Deadline task** to keep track of something that must be done before a specific date/time.
Got it. I've added this deadline:
Now you have 3 tasks in the list.
A Todo task represents a simple activity without any specific deadline.
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 4 tasks in the list.
An Event has a start and end time — for example, a meeting or a conference.
with start time and end time following the format: `yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm`
Got it. I've added this event:
Now you have 5 tasks in the list.
Display all current tasks in your list.
Mark a task as done or not done.
I've marked this task as done:
Remove a task from the list by its number.
Now you have 4 tasks in the list.
Find tasks that contain a keyword in their description.
Here are the matching tasks in your list:
Starou automatically saves your tasks to: `./data/Starou.txt`
Each time you start the chatbot, it loads the saved tasks automatically.
Starou will say goodbye and exit gracefully:
| `todo <description>`                                    | Adds a simple task without a deadline. | `todo read book` |
| `deadline <description> /by <time>`                     | Adds a task with a specific deadline. | `deadline submit report /by 2025-10-10 23:59` |
| `event <description> /from <start time> /to <end time>` | Adds an event with start and end times. | `event project meeting /from 2025-10-12 14:00 /to 2025-10-12 16:00` |
| `list`                                                  | Displays all tasks in your list. | `list` |
| `mark <index>`                                          | Marks the specified task as completed. | `mark 2` |
| `unmark <index>`                                        | Marks the specified task as not completed. | `unmark 2` |
| `delete <index>`                                        | Deletes the specified task from the list. | `delete 3` |
| `find <keyword>`                                        | Searches for tasks that contain the given keyword. | `find meeting` |
- Make sure your time follow the format: `yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm`
- Use lowercase commands (`todo`, `deadline`, etc.) — commands are case-sensitive.
* The main class of the Starou chatbot application.
* Starou is a simple command-line task management assistant that supports adding,
* listing, deleting, marking, unmarking, and finding tasks. It also saves and loads tasks
* Prints a formatted box around the given lines of text.
* Each line is prefixed with two spaces, and surrounded by horizontal borders.
* This helps format the chatbot responses for better readability.
* @param lines one or more strings to print inside the box
* The main entry point of the Starou chatbot.
* Initializes the application, loads existing tasks from file storage, and listens
* for user input via the console until the user types {@code bye}.
* Supported commands include: {@code list}, {@code mark}, {@code unmark},
* {@code delete}, {@code find}, {@code todo}, {@code deadline}, and {@code event}.
printBox("Hello! I'm Starou from Vietnam", "What can I do for you?");
System.out.println("Here are the matching tasks in your list:");

"Unknown command. Try: list, todo, deadline, event, mark, unmark, delete bye.");

printBox("Task index must be a positive interger!");

* Handles reading and writing of {@link Task} data to and from a persistent text file.
* The {@code Storage} class allows the Starou application to save user tasks
* and restore them in future sessions. Tasks are serialized in a simple
private static final DateTimeFormatter formatter = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm");
* Constructs a new {@code Storage} object for managing task data at the specified path.
* Loads tasks from the save file.
* If the file does not exist or is empty, an empty list is returned.
* Each line in the file is parsed into a corresponding {@link Task}
* instance such as {@link Todo}, {@link Deadline}, or {@link Event}.
* @return a list of tasks loaded from the file (never {@code null})
System.err.println("[WARN] Failed to read save file: " + e.getMessage());

* The expected format for each task is:
* Lines that do not match these formats are ignored.
* @param line a single line from the save file
* @return the parsed {@link Task}, or {@code null} if the line is invalid or corrupted
Event e = new Event(parts[2], from, to);

* The {@code Parser} class provides utility methods to parse user input
* into {@link Task} objects or specific command arguments.
* It supports parsing commands for creating {@link Todo}, {@link Deadline},
* and {@link Event} tasks, as well as finding keywords in the task list.
* Invalid or malformed commands result in an {@link InvalidCommandException}.
private static final DateTimeFormatter formatter = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm");
* Determines whether a user input string represents a valid add command.
* A command is considered an "add" command if it starts with
* @param input the raw user input string
* @return {@code true} if the input starts with an add command keyword; {@code false} otherwise
* Parses a user input string and constructs the corresponding {@link Task} object.
* @param input the full user command string
* @return a {@link Task} instance of type {@link Todo}, {@link Deadline}, or {@link Event}
* @throws InvalidCommandException if the command format is invalid or unsupported
throw new InvalidCommandException("Please enter a valid command!");
throw new InvalidCommandException("Unknown command! Try: todo, deadline, event!");
* Parses a {@code todo} command and constructs a {@link Todo} task.
* @param s the user input starting with {@code todo}
* @throws InvalidCommandException if the description is missing or empty
throw new InvalidCommandException("Please enter task description after todo!");
* Parses a {@code deadline} command and constructs a {@link Deadline} task.
* @param s the user input starting with {@code deadline}
* @return a new {@link Deadline} task with its due date
* @throws InvalidCommandException if description or {@code /by} clause is missing or invalid
throw new InvalidCommandException("Deadline needs a description and '/by <time>' !");
throw new InvalidCommandException("Please enter a value after '/by' !");
throw new InvalidCommandException("Deadline description cannot be empty.");
* Parses an {@code event} command and constructs an {@link Event} task.
* @param s the user input starting with {@code event}
* @return a new {@link Event} task with start and end times
* @throws InvalidCommandException if description, {@code /from}, or {@code /to} parts are missing or invalid
throw new InvalidCommandException("Event needs a description and '/from ... /to ...' !");
throw new InvalidCommandException("Please enter a description!");
* Extracts the keyword from a {@code find} command for searching tasks.
* @param input the full user command string
* @return the keyword following the {@code find} command
* @throws InvalidCommandException if the keyword is missing or empty
throw new InvalidCommandException("Please enter a valid keyword!");
throw new InvalidCommandException("Please enter a keyword after 'find'!");
* Represents an abstract task in the Starou task management system.
* A {@code Task} stores a textual description and whether it has been completed.
* Subclasses such as {@link Todo}, {@link Deadline}, and {@link Event}
* must define their specific type icon and storage format.
* Constructs a new {@code Task} with the given description.
* The task is initially marked as not done.
* @param description the textual description of the task
* Returns the status icon representing the task’s completion state.
* The icon is {@code "X"} if the task is done, or a single space {@code " "}
return isDone ? "X" : " "; //X if the task is done, blank if the task isn't
* Returns the type icon that identifies the subclass of the task.
* Implementations must define a one-character symbol representing
* their task type (e.g., {@code "T"} for Todo, {@code "D"} for Deadline).
* Returns additional information for display, if applicable.
* Subclasses may override this to append extra details such as
* @return a string containing extra task information, or an empty string if none
* Returns a string representation of this task for saving to persistent storage.
* Each subclass must define how its information is serialized
* (e.g., type, completion status, and any extra data).
* @return the formatted storage string for this task
* Returns a user-friendly string representation of this task.
* The format includes the type icon, completion status, and description,
* followed by any extra info defined by {@link #extraInfo()}.
* @return a string representation suitable for display in the console
String base = String.format("[%s][%s] %s", getTypeIcon(), getStatusIcon(), description);
